nodes.bodyText: I will start using channel attributes for now and reconsider approach when all events will be implemented. Don't want to change the internal API to propagate it correctly until I see the whole picture. For now, this PR focuses on behavior correctness for notified events.

Generally for all builders; should this be a Supplier<TransportObserver>?
Specifically for multi-address client; we should have a way to provide per host observer

TransportObserver works as a factory for ConnectionObservers. So, I don't think we need a supplier here.
For multi-address builder we have a general problem that most of the options are not per-client (except security config and filters). Taking into account that TransportObserver may move to the ConnectionFactory I will defer this enhancement.

Supplier is needed as many clients can be built from the same builder. It is completely fair to ask folks to set a new TransportObserver every time they create a client, is that what you intend? If so, then this is what makes the multi-address client case harder. Can we avoid adding this to multi-address client or at least follow the secure() method model where someone can provide a TransportObserver for a HostAndPort?
Updated multi-address client builder to build a TransportObserver per HostAndPort.
I am generally concerned about creating such publicly accessible, broadly scoped utilities prematurely.
This is an internal utility.

Sure but it is a public class. Do we really want a whole utility to get and set from a channel attribute?
In any case, now it can be package private I think?

Can we do this assignment in TcpServerBinder? ChannelSet is just a means to have a collection of channels for a server; adding this functionality here seems incorrect. Additionally it increases the scope of TransportObserverUtils outside the tcp-netty-internal module
Good call, let me move it from ChannelSet to a better place.

In which cases does the closeFuture() complete with an error?
I think this usage does not map to your intent of connectionClosed(Throwable) contract, does it?
The cases are represented in TcpServerTransportObserverErrorsTest. The error may happen in the pipeline or in the ConnectionAcceptor.

You are decoupling observer creation from channel initialization. Is the intent here to account for time delta between start of connect and call to init() here?
The init sequence of creating an observer and adding the transport handler seems convoluted. Have you thought about creating the observer in this method?

Correct, the intend was to create a ConnectionObserver as soon as we have access to the Channel. But you are right, there is not much between the netty's initChannel and the current init method. Moved it to TransportObserverInitializer and it looks much better. Thanks!
Can we also hook in close events to the observer using this handler instead of the close future?
That will lose errors outside of the pipeline.

nodes.bodyText:
The method names here are in past tense "dataWritten", "flushed", etc. Is this intentional that they are associated with timing? While invoking these callbacks we are not consistent; dataRead() is after we have read from socket, dataWritten() is before we have written to the socket.
An alternate is to use onDataRead, onDataWrite, onFlush ... etc or whenDataRead, whenFlushed which hides the timing (before/after) and are also similar to the callbacks on our async primitives.

nodes.bodyText: Thanks for the suggestion! I moved the code from ChannelSet to another place.

IIUC, the current code paths registering an error is a subset of things you would want to cover eventually.
Looks like we need to have some association with the close-handler to determine which error should be the cause of closure instead of this "first-writer-wins" semantics?

Not sure about CloseHandler because a Channel may be closed from different places. After investigating different closure cases it looks acceptable to use "first-writer-wins" semantics because channels are always closed right after observing an error.

Not sure about CloseHandler because a Channel may be closed from different places.

Sure close can be initiated from multiple places but close-handler holds the close state machine (for H1).
Having the determination here that the first error is important and the rest are silently ignored essentially is ignoring the state represented by the close state machine (close handler for h1 and netty for h2).
This change only contains 2 calls to this method, how about we determine the mechanism to handle connection errors as a follow-up when we have a better idea about how to handle the reason for close holistically.
its somewhat awkward to handle the ConnectionObserver in the ChannelSet on the server, and directly in the transport code for the client. did you consider moving this into the transport as well?
